comments.commentBody:
I've split the last 25 years between the U.S. and Japan. In Japan, the trains are clean and run on time and there is almost no crime. People are generally curteous, friendly, well-educated (K-12 education in Japan puts the U.S. to shame), trustworthy and trusting. Japan's good values, including about food, nutrition, consumption and the environment, should be a lesson to others. Life here is good, the way it should be.

The media has painted Japan with the brush of "stagnation" and the labeled the 1990s and even the 2000s as the "lost decade," but Stiglitz is spot on. Maintaining the status quo from a point of stability, health high education, high employment, high personal savings and comfrot is something quite different from regression or maintenance of the status quo in a society that lacks all of the above.

In the U.S., the infrastructure is crumbling. Our electric grid desperately needs an upgrade. Bridges, tunnels, subways and sewer systems are old and falling apart. Millions of people go without effective access to healthcare (even after Obamacare). American ills include poverty, obescity, poor public education, lack of educational and economic opportunities, high crime, racial tensions, illegal drugs, societal distrust, and the constant stress associated with these ills. Japan isn't perfect by any means, but with a few exceptions the ills listed here are not a significant part of normal life here. Your perception could not be further from my reality.

"It is every citizen's duty to do what they think is right and proper and not be bound by loyalty oaths and secrecy constraints when they conclude the country's integrity is at stake. That is what a whistleblower is."

I disagree. Either a person's word means something or it does not. If each of us can ignore our legal agreements and sworn oaths and take matters into our own hands based upon our personal perceptions and ethics then we are all in big trouble.

"The people are supposed to trust this kind of government implicitly and allow an elite cadre of insiders to decide what is in the interests of the country?"

Instead, we are supposed to trust high school dropouts and leakers employing subjective ethics to decide what is in the interests of the country? I did not elect Snowden to decide for me; none of us did. That is not how a republic functions.

A couple more Mannings and Snowdens coming along, and you won't have to worry about the constitution. There won't be a country left to bother about if all the public servants decide to do whatever they feel like doing based on their "gut" feelings, instead of what they are told to do.  I would make examples of both these traitors before its too late.  Whistleblowing about torture is one thing.  This latest stuff is nothing more than grandstanding by a couple of low lifes.

This analysis completely ignores Snowden's stated reason for doing what he did. He has said he thought the public should have a say in breath and depth of what the government is doing with its massive security apparatus and put himself in jeopardy to accomplish that goal. That's hardly the behavior of a loner who is concerned only with his own freedoms. It is every citizen's duty to do what they think is right and proper and not be bound by loyalty oaths and secrecy constraints when they conclude the country's integrity is at stake. That is what a whistleblower is.

This report seems more concerned that the elite Washington consensus be maintained, ignoring that it rubber stamped the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, promoted the creation of a massive security apparatus, that has shredded the constitution and past norms regarding torture and indefinite detention, that has equipped local police departments with military style hardware, and that has been going after whistleblowers with a vengeance and intimidating the press.

The people are supposed to trust this kind of government implicitly and allow an elite cadre of insiders to decide what is in the interests of the country? We need more people like Bradley Manning and Edward Snowden if our runaway government is once again to be made responsive to the will of the people, not just an elite Washington consensus and the corporations that finance them and profit from government contracts.

With my senior citizen's agreement, I reached out to all of the nonprofits and asked them to remove her from their mailing/solicitation lists. I also got her name on the national "do not call' registry. She also has a phone that lets me see incoming phone numbers, however, it's harder to reach a real person on the other end to get off the lists when calling in.
I think you have it backwards. Elizabeth Warren is the only one with enough guts to take on the banks.
It used to be that a lobbyist would get a Congressperson to write a bill for them.  Now in many cases, corporations are writing the bills, and Congress doesn't even read much of what passes.

Take care of yourself!  It is not the government's job nor does the government have the ability  to protect you from yourself.  Note to elderly, I don't care how lonely you are, if the phone rings and the caller isn't a trusted friend or family member, HANG UP!   You initiate the call, call a friend, call your relative, call a hot line, call your church.   Don't talk to strangers on the phone and you will not be scammed this way.

I hate to say it but it's looking more like fascism when corporations take over our government and write the laws. It's definitely not democracy, our representatives no longer represent us and our best interests.

And the financial industry has lobbying firms who have gotten Senators to water down the reforms put into place after the 2008 meltdown.  Wow, our elected representatives are really taking care of us.

A similar scam perpetuated by banks -- and permitted by the Banking Law of 1990 -- is that they'll cash obviously fraudulent checks without even looking at them. (Literally - they run them thru machines by the millions.). They'll cash a check signed in a childlike scrawl bearing no resemblance to the depositor's signature, they'll cash a check written in crayon, they'll cash a check with no signature at all.

The depositor bears the onus of checking his or her bank statement for stolen or unauthorized checks each month within thirty days. If you miss the first month of fraud, but catch the second, you lose the right to *any* reimbursement, even for the fraud reported on the second statement, on the theory that if you'd duly checked the first statement, it would've prevented the fraud reported on the second.

This is all legal under the 1990 law. It impacts the elderly the most, since they're more forgetful about checking their statements and are more easily confused. They also are often tended to by a home health aide on a daily basis, who could easily learn where the check books are kept, and even find and use the key to unlock the drawer or file cabinet.

Adult kids, look out for your elderly parents, and especially any child-free aunts and uncles!

I'm old enough to remember when you could leave doors unlocked while on vacation, leave the keys in the unlocked car when shopping, leave your baby outside the store in his carriage, let your kids run free.....and nothing bad would happen. Those were the days these Seniors remember. It must be difficult to have to recognize that today it's a dog eat dog world in America.
Oooh, sounds like the notorious nanny state at work! And you didn't feel demeaned and insulted? Your freedom to be defrauded was take away from you by an overreaching government!

You can't blame the post office or letter carriers.  If mail has been stamped, they are required to deliver it.  With some restrictions for firearms and such.  I just toss the junk mail into my recycling bin.
Mail carriers must deliver what's addressed properly and has sufficient postage. They aren't the "perps".

Note to Steve and Jeffrey: It's evident that you do not have first-hand experience with mail fraud and elders.

Once the scammers identify a mark, they don't let go. They get the phone number, and they invite the mark to meet them at the local box store to pick up their winnings. They send bills that look like tax bills and medical bills. They might phone, pretending to be a relative.

And it's the post office that makes it all possible. The post office doesn't deliver child porn. They shouldn't deliver scams targeting old people.

Yes, the banks are crooks. But so is the United States Post Office.

The letter carriers know who's being scammed - they deposit the stacks of "You have won!" envelopes going into the mail boxes of the old and clueless.

The Bulk Mail Processing Centers know. After all, only a fool would think that thousands of different individuals could each be the winner.

And the Postmaster General knows. He knows that aiding and abetting the fleecing of our elders is a very nice profit center for the USPS.

And Congress does nothing about it.
If you have a smartphone, the applications you download often spy on your calls, your address book, have the ability to make phone calls, and more.  It's crazy.

Exactly. I put my phone number on the Do Not Call registry a while ago, but the older I get, the more scammer calls I get--at least one a week now.
In this era of no privacy, it's easy to find out anyone's age on the Internet. I'm certain the scammers are targeting the elderly. I called AT&T to inquire about getting an unlisted phone number--guess what? They would charge me $5 a month for the privilege! I think anyone ought to have the right to have an unlisted phone number for free.

As explained by an earlier NYT article, most of these robocallers have gone offshore, so the FCC has no way of enforcing the do not call program.  I just click on answer for a few seconds and then hang up if it's a number I don't recognize.

My wife and I are over 70 tears old and although we have  recorded our telephone under a privacy do not call program we receive several calls a day of outfits trying to scare us into buying products that would supposedly protect us in case of emergency and simultaneously collect our financial information.  Why the telephone privacy laws aren't more effectively enforced? The banks are enablers of these criminal behaviors but the primary culprits are the companies that engage in the fraudulent calls. We have the right to have a telephone without the fear of it being used as a criminal tool.

Not only is it cruel, it's bigoted. You don't know anything about these people except that they're old. To tie them in with tea party conservatives is way outside your purview. Perhaps it rationalizes things so that you can sleep tonight, do nothing to help and pretend that you're some sort of activist.

Shame on anyone who uses a story like this to score political points against complete strangers.

We have the best political system the banks and corporations own. These days we don't choose the politicians, they choose their voters through gerrymandering and likely voter lists broken down to the level of individual people.

The American people deserve far better.

Both dems and republicans in Congress are bought by the big banks....except Congress woman Elizabeth Warren and maybe a handful of others. Our democracy is in trouble and we need to have campaign reform now.

All of these incidents are lamentable and tragic. That being said, we must come to terms with the fact that we have the government and the financial system that we as American citizens have chosen and, therefore, deserve.

I suppose some would consider it cruel were I to ask how many of these elderly victims enthusiastically cast their ballots for Tea Party and other rightwing politicians who create a political climate that resists government regulation and makes these sorts of predatory practices not only possible, but acceptable.
Any different from believing that TeaParty has seniors' best interest in mind?
Is this any different that being mugged?
What is ironic is that banks rake legitimate small businesses over the coals with their draconian underwriting policies and ridiculous fees, while giving these completely fraudulent operators a pass.

If you believe that you have no control whatsoever as a parent -- that children as young as TEN (in fourth grade!) cannot be controlled whatsoever -- that sexual urges are so strong that NOBODY can deny them (even long enough to buy a 50 cent condom) -- then you will end up with a society where it is the norm for 10 and 11 year old girls to be having sex (with much older adult men).

And what if that young teenager has been repeatedly raped by her father, step-father, grandfather, uncle or brother? Ya think just maybe she'd be afraid to tell her parents?
Life isn't perfect.

I wonder how many under-18 girls endured abortion, miscarriage or childbirth because of an unintended pregnancy, in the months the administration delayed this decision. That's a tragedy.

No reasonable person wants to see a young teen-ager become pregnant before she is physically, emotionally and financially ready; but unfortunately, the raging hormones cannot just be wished away until later. If your daughter needs the morning-after pill, she needs to be able to get it to avoid an unintended pregnancy. Equally important for her development are open communication with her parents about sex and romance and also perhaps, with a trusted aunt or other adult, as well as reasonable parental supervision.

@Theodosius
The obtuseness is yours. The safety of the drug is an integral part of the morality of issuing it since the moral question is one of benefits against harms. You have a safe drug that can curtail teenage pregnancy...a salutary goal.

Your straw man about parental consent presupposes that every teenage comes from a family environment where that candor is possible. Odds are that a teenager will be far less likely to do an end run where the family relationship is strong; the ones from the dysfunctional families are more likely to need to be able to use Plan B without such consent.

Further, people on this very thread have been trotting out claims of the drug's potential side effects, so to argue that Plan B's safety isn't "pertinent to the discussion" only means that you haven't been paying attention.

" there is literally no such thing as an unwanted child. "
There is certainly such a thing as an unwanted pregnancy.
What took them so long?

This is the result Obama wanted from the start. He drew the attention of the courts onto his own administration so that the courts would demand that the pill be made available. By seeming to be opposed, he took the conservatives' position and let the courts strike it down as quickly as possible. Now, the conservatives can't fuss because the courts have already done their work. So it is free sailing for plan B and the reactionaries can't do a thing about it. Obama is one smart cookie, in case there was any doubt.

Eric: Children are never "unwanted," since couples desiring to adopt exceed the number of available children put up for adoption. It is never good to let the facts get in the way of a punch line.
Wissdid: Hey, I'm from the Midwest where we actually teach children things like virtue and the importance of morality, instead of the encouragement of "sexual expression" and other modern euphemisms for child sex. C.f. the schoolteacher in Brave New World who forces her students into sexual experimentation on the playground. As for the scenario of the rapist stepfather, keep in mind that the girl can always request a DNA test which would prove the stepfather committed statutory rape.
nomidalamerda: You refuse to reply with real argument and instead fall back on ad hominem. Because of my word-choice, I must be a anti-choicer, whose views and opinions thus ought to be summarily dismissed, without being given a hearing. A very clever--if out-worn and trite--method of avoiding argument. Parents do own their children, at least until they're 18. This is the United States, not the Brook Farm of yore or a Danish hippie commune.
judgeroybean: That's the way: employ the knock-down argument from chronological snobbery (i.e. "Practice X happened in the past, therefore, X must be wrong/bad/undesirable.)
Orphan Black breaks that. They do it all the time.

You rightly note:"...national and local banks are technical geniuses in keeping up with the minutiae of hundreds of millions of transactions in customers' checking accounts." Yes, yet we still don't have a safe national voting process or machines we can trust to register and tabulate our votes accurately.

Thomas Bishop -

What do you mean based on rationality and science ?

Does a parent have the right to control the sexuality of a 10 year old? Is there ANY age where the parental right trumps the right of an individual?

Because if there is not, then you can throw all parental rights out the door.

I know girls of EIGHT who have started their periods, and can probably technically get pregnant -- they have breasts and pubic hair. This is not uncommon in certain populations.

I have friends who are social workers and say that "nobody is remotely shocked anymore when a 10 year old shows up pregnant".

If you are 10, and your statutory rapist wants to have condom-free sex with you, all he needs to do is shell out $45 each time now (cheap!) and nobody will have any evidence as to what he is doing to you.
WellRead29 - you're worried about side affects of Plan B but would prefer your daughter was pregnant and deal with it then? I suggest you look up the side affects of pregnancy.

"[mr. obama] said that as the father of two young girls, the idea of making the drug available to them without a prescription made him uncomfortable."

why would it make you feel uncomfortable, mr. obama? perhaps it makes you feel uncomfortable imagining if your daughters needed to use the drug, but if they would need to use it, then it should be readily available, right?

in any case, policy for the whole nation (and probably decisions about when/how to have family discussions about sexuality as well) should not be made based on how "uncomfortable" a person is about sexual ideas. it should be made based on rationality and science.

Jim,
Anything it is possible to live without (and, yes, it is possible to live one's entire life without engaging in sexual intercourse), cannot define what makes us human. So, no, sex is not "exactly what makes us human"--not by a long-shot.

Bobcats make that sound.  I've heard them many times and know that it was the bobcat because once it was standing in my driveway making the scream while it stalked my cat.  I researched it a little bit and there seems to be two schools of thought; one that says it is a mating sound and another that says it makes the sound to scare its prey into freezing as it hunts.  I also saw a catamount in the Catskills about 15 years ago.  Though the rangers insist it must have been a bobcat, I know the difference.  This was a huge tawny cat with a tail as long as its body.

Deer populations have exploded, and cougars hunting the deer will be a major aid in culling the herds (one wonders if auto insurers might appreciate the help, given the number of deer/auto accidents that happen).
